Effects of ancillary ligands on molecular structure and catalytic properties of tridentate α-sulfonate-β-diimine nickel complexes toward ethylene (co)polymerization Donghui Li Writing – original draft Data curation Zonglin Qiu Software Formal analysis Xieyi Xiao Formal analysis Heng Gao Data curation Chunyu Feng Formal analysis Handou Zheng Writing – review & editing Methodology Funding acquisition ⁎ Haiyang Gao Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Conceptualization ⁎ School of Materials Science and Engineering, PCFM Lab, GD HPPC Lab, DSAPM Lab, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou 510275, China School of Materials Science and Engineering PCFM Lab, GD HPPC Lab, DSAPM Lab, Sun Yat-sen University Guangzhou 510275 China School of Materials Science and Engineering, PCFM Lab, GD HPPC Lab, DSAPM Lab, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou 510275, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. In the design of olefin polymerization catalysts, ancillary ligands attract less attention than ligands and the effects of ancillary ligands on olefin polymerization has been rarely studied because they are commonly regarded as auxiliary complexing agents for transition metal complexes. We herein report the synthesis and characterization of a series of tridentate α-sulfonate-β-diimine nickel complexes with coordinating solvents (CH3CN, PhCN, THF, and H2O) to study the effects of ancillary ligands on the molecular structure of complexes and catalytic properties toward ethylene (co)polymerization. Ancillary ligands impact the geometry and stabilization of α-sulfonate-β-diimine nickel complexes, which are closely related to their coordination ability to the metal center. Ethylene (co)polymerization results show that ancillary ligands have an important influence on polymerization activity and thermal stabilization of the catalyst through their dissociation from the metal and the coordination completion between ancillary ligands and ethylene monomer. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nickel complex Ancillary ligand Catalyst Ethylene Polymerization Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Transition metal catalysts have played a dominant role in the field of catalytic olefin polymerization, which offers the means to control structural variations in the molecular architecture of polyolefin materials [1–4]. Design and development of transition metal olefin polymerization catalysts has attracted long-standing interest. Metal-ligand combinations that arise upon coordination of the ligand to the metal serve both to tune the electronic properties of the metal, and to modulate the steric environment around the metal center, thereby allowing for control over the molecular structure and reactivity of metal complexes [5]. Based on the modes of organic or main-group molecules and ions that bind to metal centers, they can be divided into ligands and ancillary ligands (or reactive ligands) (Fig. 1 ) [6]. In the design of transition metal olefin polymerization catalysts, ligand design and synthesis attract more attention than that of ancillary ligands because ligands can directly modulate the reactivity of a metal center [7–10]. As a matter of fact, ancillary ligands undergo chemical changes, including irreversible chemical transformations or dissociation from the metal as metal complexes are activated for olefin polymerization [11–16]. Therefore, ancillary ligands also play an important role in olefin catalysis. The effects of ancillary ligands on Ni/Pd-catalyzed ethylene (co)polymerization have been previously studied, highlighting their impacts on activity, catalyst stability, branching, and associated isomerization. Brookhart [17], Harth [18,19], and Jian [20] groups reported the effects of ancillary ligands (nitrile, aluminum chloride (AlCl3), and polar solvents) on branching and associated isomerization in α-diimine palladium-catalyzed polymerization of ethylene and α-olefins (A). Our group also observed that the presence of the ancillary ligand acetonitrile (CH3CN) in the dibenzobarrelene derived α-diimine palladium-catalyzed ethylene polymerization can compete with the ethylene monomer for coordination, thereby impacting polymerization activity and catalyst thermostability (A) [21]. Mecking and Jian observed the effects of ancillary ligands on activity, branching microstructure, and molecular weight in salicylaldiminato nickel-catalyzed ethylene polymerization (B) [22,23]. Agapie and coworkers highlighted the potential of a strategy involving the effects of ancillary ligand (triethylphosphine (PEt3), triphenylphosphine (PPh3), pyridine) to improve catalyst activity in phosphine enolate and phosphine phenolate nickel-catalyzed copolymerization of ethylene and acrylate (C) [24]. For neutral phosphine sulfonate palladium catalysts, ancillary ligands mainly impact polymerization activity by changing catalyst initiation and propagation (D) [25–32]. Despite significant contributions, current studies on the effects of ancillary ligands on olefin polymerization are limited to bidentate Ni/Pd catalysts with a square-planar geometry. To the best of our knowledge, the effects of ancillary ligands on tridentate Ni/Pd-catalyzed olefin polymerization have never been studied. We can envision that tridentate Ni/Pd complexes would have different geometries compared with the bidentate square-planar Ni/Pd complexes, thus showing different effects of ancillary ligands. Previously, we reported that the neutral tridentate α-sulfonato-β-diimine nickel complex with an apical SO3–Ni coordination has a distorted square pyramidal geometry [33]. The α-sulfonate-β-diimine nickel catalyst can catalyze ethylene polymerization to produce branched PE with selective branching and copolymerization of ethylene and alkyl acrylate or norbornene to afford branched copolymers [34]. In this contribution, a series of α-sulfonate-β-diimine nickel complexes with different ancillary ligands (CH3CN, benzonitrile (PhCN), tetrahydrofuran (THF), and water (H2O)) were synthesized and employed in ethylene (co)polymerization. Ancillary ligands not only impact the molecular structure of nickel complexes, but also affect the catalytic properties for ethylene homopolymerization and copolymerization with methyl acrylate. Importantly, beyond steric and electronic tuning of the ligands, ancillary ligands can enhance the thermal stability of catalyst. Results and discussion Synthesis and characterization of nickel complexes We have previously reported a neutral tridentate α-sulfonate-β-diimine nickel complex Ni1 (see Scheme 1 ), which contains a Br group and a coordinating CH3CN ancillary ligand [33,34]. Herein, we aim to synthesize a series of α-sulfonate-β-diimine nickel complexes with different coordinating molecules to study the effects of ancillary ligands. α-Sulfonate-β-diimine nickel complexes were prepared by the reaction of α-sulfonate-β-diimine lithium salts [35] and NiBr2·3H2O in different solvents such as CH3CN, PhCN, THF, and toluene (PhMe) (Scheme 1). All isolated nickel complexes were clearly characterized by elemental analysis and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). For example, the characteristic vibrations of ancillary ligands such as CH3CN, PhCN, THF, and H2O were observed at 2362 (CN of CH3CN), 2229 (CN of PhCN), 1008 (C–O of THF), and 3410 (O–H of H2O) cm-1 in the FT-IR spectra of complexes Ni1-Ni4, respectively (Fig. S1). Effects of ancillary ligands on molecular structure Single crystals of nickel complexes Ni2-Ni4 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by slow evaporation of their solution, while a single crystal of nickel complex Ni1 was obtained from the nickel complex Ni5 solution in CH3CN (see below the discussion on Ni5 molecular structure). As shown in Fig. 2 , all nickel complexes Ni1-Ni4 have a five-coordinate model, and solvent molecules act as ancillary ligands coordinating with the nickel metal center. The Ni–SO3 distances of complexes Ni1-Ni4 are short (2.03∼2.13 Å), clearly confirming that the sulfonate group coordinates to the nickel metal at its apical position. The solvent molecule acting as ancillary ligand has an influence on the geometry of α-sulfonate-β-diimine nickel complexes. Ni1 has a good square pyramidal geometry based on the metric geometric parameter (τ) calculation (τ = 0.04). With changing coordinating solvents, the τ value of nickel complexes increases (τ = 0.40 for Ni3, τ = 0.30 for Ni4), and the complex geometry shifts to a distorted trigonal bipyramidal structure. Complex Ni2 has a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry based on a τ value of 0.53 [36]. It is found that the coordinating solvent hardly impacts the steric hindrance around the nickel metal center, which can be clearly confirmed by the buried volume of complexes Ni1-Ni4 calculated by topographic steric maps (Fig. 3 ). However, the size of the coordinating solvent seems to affect its spatial position. The coordinating solvents (CH3CN, THF, H2O) lie in the orientation of the SO3 - group in complexes Ni1, Ni3, and Ni4, while the coordinating PhCN lies at the opposite orientation of the SO3 - group in complex Ni2 (see Fig. 4 ). The angles of Br–Ni–O(SO3) in nickel complexes also support the size effect of the coordinating solvent. The complex Ni2 has a smaller angle of Br–Ni–O(SO3) (86.865°) than the complexes Ni1, Ni3, and Ni4 (159.698, 144.965, 167.098°) (Table 1 ). In addition to coordinating solvents, PPh3 is usually used as an ancillary ligand in neutral olefin polymerization nickel catalysts [37–40]. We herein tried to prepare the α-sulfonate-β-diimine nickel complex Ni7 with a PPh3 ancillary ligand. Ni7 was synthesized by reacting Ni(PPh3)2Br2 with α-sulfonate-β-diimine lithium salt in PhMe (Scheme 1). Surprisingly, this reaction showed different experimental phenomenon compared to the previous reactions of nickel complexes Ni1-Ni3. The brown precipitation was in-situ formed in the reaction system, and the isolated solid of nickel complex was insoluble in no-coordinating solvents. 31P NMR analysis (Fig. S2) showed that the organic fraction from the decomposition of nickel complex did not show any phosphorus resonances, but the organic compounds in reaction filtrate displayed a clear PPh3 signal at −6.84 ppm. This result strongly indicates that the isolated nickel complex does not contain a PPh3 ancillary ligand and does not have the molecular structure of Ni7 (see Scheme 1). Attempts to synthesize nickel complex Ni7 with PPh3 ancillary ligand through nitrile complex Ni1 with triphenylphosphine were also unsuccessful. Although the isolated nickel complex was insoluble in no-coordinating solvents such as PhMe and dichloromethane (CH2Cl2), it was readily soluble in coordinating solvents such as CH3CN. A single crystal of nickel complex was obtained from the nickel complex solution in CH3CN, and its molecular structure was confirmed to be complex Ni1 (see Fig. 2). Therefore, the molecular structure of the isolated nickel complex should be a four-coordinate complex without an ancillary ligand Ni6 or its dimer, a five-coordinate Ni5 with Br bridges. In fact, these two molecular structures of Ni6 and its dimer Ni5 were difficult to distinguish through spectroscopic analysis. To confirm the molecular structure of the isolated nickel complex, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were further carried out (see computational details in the SI). As shown in Fig. 5 , the dimer Ni5 has a lower free energy ΔG than Ni6, indicating that the isolated nickel complex has a five-coordinate structure with Br bridges. Furthermore, complex Ni1 with a CH3CN ancillary ligand is more stable than Ni5 based on the calculation results, which is consistent with experimental observations mentioned above. It is known that PPh3 has stronger coordination ability (α TM = 4.3) to the metal center than CH3CN (α TM = −0.2) (Table 1) [41,42], but nickel complex Ni7 was not prepared. A reasonable explanation is that the steric repulsion between the bulky α-sulfonate-β-diimine ligand and the PPh3 ancillary ligand prohibits the coordination of PPh3 to the nickel center [39]. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of nickel complexes was further carried out to confirm their molecular structures (Fig. 6 ) [43], and results were summarized in Table 2 . Clearly, ancillary ligands have an important influence on the thermal stability of α-sulfonate-β-diimine nickel complexes. As shown in Fig. 6, complexes Ni1-Ni3 with coordinating solvents clearly show two onset decomposition temperatures while Ni5 only exhibits one onset decomposition temperature, which indicates that Ni5 has no organic molecule ancillary ligands. Complexes Ni1-Ni3 have different first onset decomposition temperatures, indicating different interaction intensities of the coordinating solvents. It is known that the coordinating ability of solvents towards transition metals can be quantitatively reflected by the coordinating ability index (α TM) [41,42]. It is found that the order of the first onset decomposition temperatures of nickel complexes (Ni2 > Ni1 > Ni3) is well consistent with the α TM values of coordinating solvents (PhCN > CH3CN > THF in Table 1). This observation indicates that the strong coordinating ability of ancillary ligands is helpful for the stability of the complexes. Experimental relative weight losses of nickel complexes Ni1-Ni3 well fit theoretical values, confirming that the relative weight loss of the first onset is a result of the dissociation of solvents. The second onset decomposition temperatures of complexes Ni1-Ni3 are nearly same as the onset decomposition temperature of complex Ni5, further supporting that Ni5 has no ancillary PPh3 ligand. Ethylene polymerization Ethylene polymerizations were screened using nickel complexes after activation with methylaluminoxane (MAO) under the same conditions to elucidate the effects of ancillary ligands on the catalytic properties of nickel complexes. As shown in Table 3 , the ethylene polymerization activity order of nickel catalysts is Ni5 > Ni3 > Ni1 > Ni4 > Ni2, which is consistent with the coordinating ability order of ancillary ligands (α TM: Ni2 > Ni4 > Ni1 > Ni3). Although Ni4 with a H2O ancillary ligand was unsuitably used to study the influence of ancillary ligands on polymerization activity because the reaction between its ancillary ligand H2O and cocatalyst MAO impacted the polymerization results. However, the ethylene polymerization activity still fits with the coordinating ability order of ancillary ligands. This observation clearly indicates that catalytic activity is closely related to the coordinating ability of ancillary ligands, which is a result of the coordination competition between ethylene and ancillary ligands (Scheme 2 ). Based on the widely accepted olefin coordination polymerization mechanism, the activation of α-sulfonate-β-diimine nickel complexes (LNiBrAL) Ni1-Ni4 by cocatalyst MAO produces methyl nickel species (LNiMe) with a vacancy through dissociation of ancillary ligands (ancillary ligand H2O is reactive with cocatalyst MAO for Ni4). Besides, the occurrence of ethylene coordination must compete with ancillary ligands during polymerization catalyzed by catalysts Ni1-Ni4. However, the activation of Ni5 by MAO does not involve the dissociation of the ancillary ligand and there is no competition for Ni5-catalyzed ethylene monomer. Resultantly, ethylene can rapidly coordinate to the nickel center and insert into the Ni–alkyl species. Therefore, Ni5 has the highest activity, and the catalyst activity increases as the decreasing coordinating ability of ancillary ligands [24,26]. The molecular weight of PEs produced by the four nickel catalysts follows the same trend as the activity (Ni5 > Ni3 > Ni1 > Ni4 > Ni2), which can be interpreted by kinetic molecular weight (M W = R p/R t, R p: chain propagation rate, R t: chain transfer rate). Ni5 shows the highest activity, therefore having the highest chain propagation rate R p. Assuming the same chain transfer rate R t for five catalysts, Ni5 affords the highest molecular weight polymer. Additionally, the ancillary ligand has no impact on PE branching structure because of the nearly the same steric and electronic environment around the nickel center. The four catalysts have nearly same branching density and melting temperature. 13C NMR analysis of PEs displayed that only methyl and long-chain branches (Fig. S4 and S6) were observed, which can be explained by limited chain walking mechanism [33]. Scattered DSC curves should be a result of different type of branches and different branching distributions. Ni5 was chosen to study the influence of polymerization temperature (entries 5–9 in Table 3). As the increasing temperatures from 0 to 100 °C, the activity of Ni5 first increases and then decreases. Ni5 exhibits the highest activity of 89.0 × 103 g PE / (mol Ni h) at 50 °C. The molecular weight of the resultant PE follows the same temperature effect, but molecular weight distribution becomes broader at high temperatures (>50 °C). As shown in Fig. 7 , the Gel permeation chromatography (GPC) curves of resultant PEs produced below 50 °C have monomodal GPC profiles (M w/M n =1.9∼2.6) while those obtained at high temperatures (80 and 100 °C) show a bimodal distribution (Fig. 7). Because the high temperature is favorable to initiation processes and polymer solubility, bimodal distribution is not a result of initiation processes and polymer aggregation. Besides, the cross-linking can be excluded because of PE polymer are fully soluble in solvent. It is deduced that bimodal distribution strongly indicates catalyst Ni5 decomposition at high temperatures. Previously, we reported that Ni1 has good thermal stability and produces monomodal distribution PE (M w/M n < 2.0) at a high temperature of 100 °C [33]. This significant difference in thermal tolerance of the nickel catalyst is attributed to the stabilization effect of the ancillary ligand on the catalytic species. The ancillary ligand makes the catalytic species more stable at high temperatures, thereby showing longer life [21]. Copolymerization of ethylene and methyl acrylate As one of few nickel catalysts for the copolymerizaiton of ethylene and methyl acrylate (MA), catalyst Ni1 has been previously reported to be able to produce branched ethylene-methyl acrylate (EMA) copolymers with both high molecular weight and high MA incorporation (up to 10 mol %) [33]. Herein, copolymerizaitons of ethylene and methyl acrylate were carried out using four nickel catalysts to study the effects of ancillary ligands on copolymerization. As shown in Table 4 , the copolymerization activity order of nickel catalysts is Ni5 > Ni3 > Ni1 > Ni2, which follows ethylene homopolymerization activity. This observation clearly indicates that copolymerization activity is related to the coordinating ability of the ancillary ligands. Additionally, the incorporation of the MA is also consistent with the coordinating ability of ancillary ligands. For the most active catalyst Ni5, increasing the concentration of MA comonomer leads to an increase in MA incorporation, but copolymerization activity and copolymer molecular weight decrease (entries 4–6 in Table 4). A high MA incorporation up to 15.6 mol % is successfully achieved at a 0.8 M concentration of MA comonomer, which is highly challenging for previously reported nickel catalysts [44–47]. Despite the effects on copolymerization activity and MA incorporation, the ancillary ligand has no impact on the branching structure of EMA. The EMA copolymers produced by the four nickel catalysts have nearly the same branching structure and incorporation and distribution of MA on the copolymer chain. The EMA copolymers produced by Ni5 are branched products and possess moderate branching density (35–37/1000C) according to 1H NMR analyses (Fig. S10). 13C NMR analysis clearly shows the characteristic resonances of the ester at 174.61 (CO) and 51.22 ppm (MeO) (Fig. 8 ), proving the incorporation of the terminal MA unit based on previous assignments for terminal chain MA units [48–54]. Generally, catalysts Ni1 and Ni5 produce EMA with nearly the same microstructure, suggesting that they should have the same copolymerization mechanism involving 2,1-insertion of MA and chain walking, except for the dissociation of the ancillary ligand and competition between MA and ancillary ligand (Scheme 2) [33]. Conclusions We have successfully synthesized and characterized a series of tridentate α-sulfonate-β-diimine nickel complexes with/without coordinating solvents (CH3CN, PhCN, THF, and H2O). Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of nickel complexes and DFT calculations confirm that all tridentate α-sulfonate-β-diimine nickel complexes exhibit a five-coordinate structure. The coordinating solvents, acting as ancillary ligands, significantly impact the geometry and stabilization of these complexes, with effects closely linked to their coordination ability to the metal center. Ethylene (co)polymerization results demonstrate that ancillary ligands play a crucial role in influencing polymerization activity and thermal stabilization of catalysts. The coordination ability of the ancillary ligands is closely related to their dissociation from the metal, which in turn affects catalyst activation. The coordination completion between ancillary ligands and ethylene monomer during ethylene (co)polymerization affects chain growth rate and stability of catalysts. Our work clearly discloses the pivotal roles that ancillary ligands play in tridentate α-sulfonate-β-diimine nickel-catalyzed ethylene (co)polymerization, highlighting that ancillary ligands are usually nonnegligible in the design of olefin polymerization catalysts. coredata.dc:description: In the design of olefin polymerization catalysts, ancillary ligands attract less attention than ligands and the effects of ancillary ligands on olefin polymerization has been rarely studied because they are commonly regarded as auxiliary complexing agents for transition metal complexes. We herein report the synthesis and characterization of a series of tridentate α-sulfonate-β-diimine nickel complexes with coordinating solvents (CH3CN, PhCN, THF, and H2O) to study the effects of ancillary ligands on the molecular structure of complexes and catalytic properties toward ethylene (co)polymerization. Ancillary ligands impact the geometry and stabilization of α-sulfonate-β-diimine nickel complexes, which are closely related to their coordination ability to the metal center. Ethylene (co)polymerization results show that ancillary ligands have an important influence on polymerization activity and thermal stabilization of the catalyst through their dissociation from the metal and the coordination completion between ancillary ligands and ethylene monomer.

coredata.dc:title: Effects of ancillary ligands on molecular structure and catalytic properties of tridentate α-sulfonate-β-diimine nickel complexes toward ethylene (co)polymerization
